document.docAuthor: Mauffray, William F. & Tennessen, Kenneth J.
document.masterDocTitle: A Catalogue and Historical Study of the Odonata of Ecuador

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A Catalogue and Historical Study of the Odonata of Ecuador

bibRefCitation.author: Hagen, H. A.
bibRefCitation.refString: Hagen, H. A. (1861) Synopsis of the Neuroptera of North America, with a list of the South American species. Smithsonian Miscellaneous Collections, Washington. Smithsonian Institution, Washington, 347 pp. https: // doi. org / 10.5962 / bhl. title. 60275

subSubSection.paragraph:
Two of the seven species are recorded for Ecuador ; see Ris (1913a , 1918 ) and
Needham et al. (2014)
for identification. Adults are slender and mostly dark ( Fig. 91 ); they perch with wings typically set down and forward over the thorax. They breed in slow streams, mostly in pooled areas, that are either open or mostly shaded.

Dythemis nigra Martin, 1897. Publ. Recs. ECU: *Kirby (1897); Maria (1938), Paulson (2011), (H14)—all as D. multipunctata ); ES: (Daigle et al. 1997), SD: (Daigle et al. 1997); ZC : Tennessen & Johnson (2008). Also ARG, BRA, CEN, GUF, GUY, PRY, PER, TTO, VEN: (P11); plus COL: (P&P); and SUR (P16).
Note: Meurgey (2010) found the true D. multipunctata on St. Vincent in the Lesser Antilles and stated that Central and South American records for D. multipunctata really represent D. nigra.

caption.paragraph: FIGURE 90. Diastatops intensa ♂, COLOMBIA, Meta Dept., pond, La Cosmopolitana, S of Cumaral, 12 x 2014, photo K. J. Ten- nessen.

subSubSection.paragraph:

sterilis ),

Note: Meurgey (2011) created the subspecies
D. sterilis sterilis
and
D. sterilis multipunctata
. Since the latter is restricted to the lesser Antilles, we simply use
D. sterilis
for the Ecuador fauna.
